title: I had a discharge in a chap 7 in July, 2010? When am I eligible to file another 7
question: I have incurred medical debt and an unsecured loan for 7,600 which I will never be able to repay
answers: Agree with the other attorneys. If you received a Chapter 7 discharge in July 2010 you can file 8 years and a day after the filing date of that initial petition roughly April 2018. You may be able to hire an attorney to negotiate on your behalf on the unsecured debt and in some cases even obtain a forgiveness of certain medical debts. Good luck.

I agree with my colleagues.
You would be entitled to a discharge of the debts you are unable to pay in a Chapter 13 filed now ... but that may not make a lot of sense (since it is considerably more expensive) if your medical debts are minimal.

If a debtor filed a prior bankruptcy and received a discharge in that bankruptcy case, then the limitation on filing is from filing date. A debtor can file a new case any time, but he/she cannot receive discharge unless the time period between filings complies with the bankruptcy code. The rule on when a new case can be filed is as simple as 2, 4, 6, 8.

2 years: ch 13 to ch 13
4 years: ch 7 to ch 13
6 years: ch 13 to ch 7
8 years: ch 7 to ch 7

If you filed a chapter 7 the first time and seven years has passed since the date you filed the first case, then you can file for relief under chapter 13 and receive a discharge. However, I have had clients tell me that they filed their prior case a certain number of years, but upon checking, the time period was much less than the client thought. You need to check your prior filing to make absolutely sure of the petition date for the prior case.

If you own no nonexempt assets and your income and expenses establish that your disposable income is low enough, then you may be able to propose a plan that pays a very small percentage to unsecured claims or possibly propose to pay $0.00 to unsecured claims at this point and dismiss the case when the 8 year mark has passed and refile a chapter 7, provided no motion to lift the automatic stay is filed before you move to dismiss that case. This option should only be considered if creditors are garnishing your pay or taking other actions to take your property. Otherwise, you are too close to reaching the 8 year mark and should wait until that date arrives.

You should meet with an experienced bankruptcy attorney that handles chapter 7 and chapter 13 cases. You may discover that a chapter 13 would be your best option even if you could file a chapter 7 and receive a discharge. Most bankruptcy attorneys will meet with you at no charge for the initial appointment. You can use the Avvo "Find a Lawyer" link at the top of this page to search for an attorney

To your question, If you have already received a discharge in a Chapter 7 bankruptcy, than you must wait eight years from the date you filed the previous case before you can file another Chapter 7 and receive a discharge (See Bankruptcy Code ยง 727(a)(8)).

If this debt is the only debt that you have, than you may wish to consider other alternatives to chapter 7 bankruptcy. I strongly suggest that you get a consultation with a local bankruptcy/debt collection defense attorney in your area.

Good luck.
You can file eight years and one day after your filing date. Based on your discharge date, I'm guess you will be eligible in April, 2018.
